results.title: James Webb telescope in Times Square
results.brief_description: As images from the James Webb telescope beam across the world, Times Square has decided to broadcast NASA’s images to the residents of NYC. The James Webb telescope is the most powerful telescope ever launched into space. President Joe Biden stated, during the first public viewing held at the White House, “It’s hard to even fathom,”, “It’s astounding. It’s an historic moment for science and technology, for America and all of humanity.”

results.title: Screen Recording of @Gutknot's TikTok post 'Tractor Goth Girl''
results.brief_description: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag.
results.title_for_label: Screen Recording of @Gutknot’s TikTok post ‘Tractor Goth Girl”
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.
description_for_label:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.

results.title: “We will adopt your baby”
results.brief_description: This week the US Supreme Court’s overturned the landmark ruling Roe v. Wade. Social media is awash with protests, political speeches, resource sharing - and memes. ‘We will adopt your baby’ is a phrase with its genesis in pro-life counter-protest signs. It has quickly become a meme deriding the offensive and unreasonable response of Christian conservatives who promote adoption as a “solution” to the dismantling of life-saving reproductive rights. Tiktok users like @tacobelldollamenu use cynical humour to reveal the lie of this rhetoric: if adoption is the solution, why does the US have a crisis in the foster system? Where are all these pro-lifers’ happily adopted kids?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

This week the US Supreme Court overturned the landmark Roe v Wade ruling . Social media is awash with protests, political speeches, resource sharing – and memes. ‘We will adopt your baby’ is a phrase that started as a slogan on pro-life counter-protest signs. It’s quickly become a meme deriding the offensive and unreasonable response of Christian conservatives who promote adoption as a “solution” to the dismantling of life-saving reproductive rights.

Tiktok users like @tacobelldollamenu use cynical humour to reveal the lie of this rhetoric: if adoption is the solution, why does the US have a crisis in the foster system? Where are all these pro-lifers’ happily adopted kids?
description_for_label: This week the US Supreme Court overturned the landmark Roe v Wade ruling. Social media is awash with protests, political speeches, resource sharing and memes. ‘We will adopt your baby’ is a phrase that started in pro-life counter-protest signs. It’s quickly become a meme deriding the offensive and unreasonable response of Christian conservatives who promote adoption as a “solution” to the dismantling of reproductive rights. TikTok users are employing cynical humour to expose the lie of this rhetoric: if adoption is the solution, why does the US have a crisis in the foster system?

results.title: Joe Biden takes a tumble
results.brief_description: US President Joe Biden fell off his bike after stopping to greet a group of reporters and members of the public while out for a ride in Delaware. Footage of the incident shared online sparked countless memes that spoofed the presidential pratfall. By splicing together videos, this Twitter user joked that it was former President Trump’s golf shot that caused the tumble.
results.description: Footage of US President Joe Biden falling from his bike has sparked countless memes spoofing the presidential pratfall. This one splices the original with Donald Trump golfing to suggest the former president is responsible for the fall. It’s a right-wing meme, but there have also been left-wing memes created to criticise Biden’s inability to achieve his more progressive policies. Both sides of politics use memes, but the alt-right, in particular, have weaponised the format’s humour and irony to spread hate.
description_for_label: Footage of US President Joe Biden falling from his bike has sparked countless memes spoofing the presidential pratfall. This one splices the original with Donald Trump golfing to suggest the former president is responsible for the fall. It’s a right-wing meme, but there have also been left-wing memes created to criticise Biden’s inability to achieve his more progressive policies. Both sides of politics use memes, but the alt-right, in particular, have weaponised the format’s humour and irony to spread hate.

results.title: Max floating to songs
results.brief_description: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past & present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

Social media users across the internet have also used special effects programs to show themselves levitating, or running out of the Upside Down from Vecna, often to their favourite songs, which they’ve edited into the visuals. This has allowed the scene to spawn numerous meme templates.

The personal element of the narrative - that your favourite song can save you from evil - and the nostalgia of the series lends itself to users contributing their own songs (and associated emotions) to the visuals, creating a personal but collective, shareable experience.

Another prominent meme created from Stranger Things 4 relies on sound. Before claiming his victims, Vecna makes them hallucinate a ticking grandfather clock (among other things) and its ominous chime (used to great effect in horror movies forever) has become an eerie indicator that he’s coming for you. Naturally, TikTokers have appropriated the sound for comedic effect. Know Your Meme traces the first use of it to user @marcusbtv, who hears it in a skit about gaming, removes one headphone and says “Nope….. not getting me”, before going back to playing.

It’s now been repurposed and reused across the internet, with users often engaging with an invisible clock (they’re hallucinating) or even Big Ben.
description_for_label: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

results.title: #MorbiusSweep
results.material_description: Digital Screen Recording of @@Rick42069's twitter feed
results.brief_description: MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This particular tweet is packed full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as Director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This tweet mixes well-known memes full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”, and satirically highlights how fandoms attempt to hijack critical responses by flooding Rotten Tomatoes with disingenuous reviews, laying bare the intersection between internet hype and movie success.
description_for_label: #MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This tweet mixes well-known memes full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”, and satirically highlights how fandoms attempt to hijack critical responses by flooding Rotten Tomatoes with disingenuous reviews, laying bare the intersection between internet hype and movie success.

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description: During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life.

constellations_primary.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_primary.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Read more

More than 200 kung fu films later, Jason Phu had his own movie to make by Kerrie O’Brien

My parents met at the fish market by Jason Phu in The Lifted Brow

Interview #34 — Jason Phu by Sophia Cai in Liminal

Storytelling with Jason Phu by Sabina McKenna in Acclaim

Who is Jason Phu? by Jane Albert in Broadsheet

“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like “Drunken Master” (1978) and “Avatar the Last Airbender” (2005–08), “Analects of Kung Phu” presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s “Dao De Jing”, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales. Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

results.title: Warlords II for DOS
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, registration card, subscription card, catalogue, advert, reply paid envelope and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords II refines on the formula that made the previous game so successful. New to the game is the addition of “fog of war”, where enemy units may be concealed from the map if a player’s own units are not close enough to see them. The interface and graphics have been upgraded and a suite of tools have been added to facilitate its multiplayer experience. This include a play by e-mail feature, a random map generator and a map editor.

results.title: Almost an Angel
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Ironbark Films and John Cornell
results.brief_description: Australian funnyman Paul Hogan stars as a thief who’s convinced he’s an angel. Hogan is career criminal Terry Dean, who’s hit by a car while saving the life of a little girl. When Terry regains consciousness, he awakens in a place strangely like heaven, with a God who looks strangely like Charlton Heston! Terry emerges from this vision believing he’s an angel - a belief that propels him and those he encounters into some howlingly funny and heartfelt predicaments.

constellations_other.name: Divining the divine
constellations_other.description: Depicting the Almighty in paintings was frowned upon in the early 1800s in Britain, much like it has been throughout the history of cinema, according to writer Scot Hughes, who made many of these connections in a 2003 article in the Sydney Morning Herald.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Paramount Pictures, Ironbark Films and John Cornell
results.description: Australian funnyman Paul Hogan stars as a thief who’s convinced he’s an angel. Hogan is career criminal Terry Dean, who’s hit by a car while saving the life of a little girl. When Terry regains consciousness, he awakens in a place strangely like heaven, with a God who looks strangely like Charlton Heston! Terry emerges from this vision believing he’s an angel - a belief that propels him and those he encounters into some howlingly funny and heartfelt predicaments.

results.title: The Animals of Farthing Wood
results.creator_credit: Philippe LeClerc, Elphin Lloyd-Jones, John Mills, BBC and EBU
results.brief_description: This is a series of animated films about the animals of Farthing Wood and their journey. They set off on a very long journey, full of adventure and excitement. Based on the bestselling books of Colin Dann.

constellations_other.name: Make it cute, make them think
constellations_other.description: Cartoons and anime are known for their dynamic and vibrant visuals, but beneath the cuteness they can also deliver powerful environmental messages and address the climate crisis.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Philippe LeClerc, Elphin Lloyd-Jones, John Mills, BBC and EBU
results.description: This is a series of animated films about the animals of Farthing Wood and their journey. Kestrel brings news that the humans are filling in the pond, and with no source of water, they would surely die. Toad advises that they should head for the nature reserve at White Deer Park. They set off on a very long journey, full of adventure and excitement. Based on the bestselling books of Colin Dann.
